utilizationMethod: Use the MacBook’s clamshell hinge as the chest lid hinge. Before VR interaction, drape a thin wood-grain adhesive film over the top cover so your fingertips feel a coarse plank texture. When the user lifts the lid, the MacBook’s built-in hinge resistance and soft-close click simulate the low-pressure friction and audible detent of a treasure chest hinge. The cold aluminum edge provides the metallic snap sensation when grasping the front lip.

virtualObjectInfo.interactivity: its hinged lid could be opened
virtualObjectInfo.hapticFeedback: When you reach out and press on the lid of the treasure chest, you should feel a slightly coarse wood-grain surface under your fingertips, with the subtle raised ridges of the planks and the occasional nail head indentation. As you grasp the front edge or the metal hasp, you get a sharper, colder metallic snap. Pulling the lid upward brings a low-pressure friction at the hinges: a smooth but noticeable resistance that ‘clicks’ into a detented open position. No overall weight shift should occur (the chest is fixed), but the lid’s hinge should impart a small tactile ‘stop’ to signal it’s fully open. A good physical proxy is a small wooden box with real metal hinges and latch, lightly sanded to leave visible wood grain and a hinge mechanism that offers gentle resistance and an audible click.

utilizationMethod: Use the back hinge barrel of the closed MacBook as the narrow cylindrical shank. Place your thumb on one side of the laptop’s curved hinge and your index finger on the other, curling them around it to mimic the key’s shaft. Then slide your fingertip along the slight beveled edge of the hinge to simulate feeling the flat facets of the key bit. While this doesn’t reproduce a ring bow, the cool, smooth aluminum and gentle bevel serve as a coarse proxy for metal feel and tooth pattern.

virtualObjectInfo.hapticFeedback: The key should feel like a cool, smooth metal object. Your thumb and index finger curl through the circular bow (ring-shaped holding part), which has a thin, uniformly rounded edge. The shank is narrow and cylindrical, leading out to the toothed bit: there you feel the distinct flat facets and sharp sawtooth pattern under mild finger pressure. A suitable proxy is a standard brass key blank—ring hole up front, slim shaft, and real machining on the teeth so you can feel each notch.

utilizationMethod: Close the MacBook lid and grab one of its thin edges between thumb and forefinger. virtualObjectInfo.description: a frisbee that players can throw
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: light weight
virtualObjectInfo.outline: holding part feels like a thin plate
virtualObjectInfo.hapticFeedback: The Frisbee should feel like a thin plastic disc: lightweight in your hand with almost no inertia, easily pinched between thumb and fingers. The rim is only a few millimeters thick but rounded, so when you flex it slightly you get a small bending sensation. The top and bottom surfaces are smooth, with just enough stiffness that the disc holds its shape but yields a bit under strong pinch. A standard plastic flying disc (real-world Frisbee) is an ideal physical proxy.

virtualObjectInfo.description: a frisbee that players can throw
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: light weight
virtualObjectInfo.outline: holding part feels like a thin plate
virtualObjectInfo.hapticFeedback: The Frisbee should feel like a thin plastic disc: lightweight in your hand with almost no inertia, easily pinched between thumb and fingers. The rim is only a few millimeters thick but rounded, so when you flex it slightly you get a small bending sensation. The top and bottom surfaces are smooth, with just enough stiffness that the disc holds its shape but yields a bit under strong pinch. A standard plastic flying disc (real-world Frisbee) is an ideal physical proxy.

utilizationMethod: Grip the MacBook’s lid edges with both hands and pivot it on its hinge axis. Use the constant friction of the hinge to simulate the steering-wheel’s low-torque drag. Sweep the lid through its open/close arc to approximate a circular turn of about 40 cm diameter by envisioning an imaginary rim around the hinge.

virtualObjectInfo.description: a steering wheel in a car
virtualObjectInfo.hapticFeedback: Place both hands on the steering wheel’s outer rim and you feel a uniform cylindrical surface—smooth but with enough diameter (≈40 cm overall) to fill your palms. As you rotate, you encounter steady, low-torque resistance that simulates mechanical friction in a car’s steering column; turning one way or the other should require constant, gentle pressure and deliver continuous haptic feedback of rotational drag. A real automotive wheel or a simulator wheel with adjustable friction is the best proxy.

utilizationMethod: Use the laptop’s rigid closed lid as a firm backing: adhere a thin silicone membrane to the top cover, fill it with a small amount of water or gel to create a bulging pouch about 0.17 m in diameter, and secure the membrane edges with elastic bands around the laptop edges. Pressing the pouch simulates the taut skin and yielding interior of a tomato against the firm support.

virtualObjectInfo.hapticFeedback: When you press the tomato between your fingers, you encounter an initially taut, slightly slippery skin that gives way under light pressure into a soft, yielding interior. As you compress further, the object deforms noticeably, and a squishy, fluid-like resistance builds before the structure collapses. A well-filled silicone stress ball or a water-balloon-style object encased in a thin rubber skin makes an excellent proxy for this smashable, compliant feel.

A well-filled silicone stress ball or a water-balloon-style object encased in a thin rubber skin makes an excellent proxy for this smashable, compliant feel.

utilizationMethod: Insert a water-filled balloon into the envelope, seal it so that the balloon presses outward, and compress through the paper envelope. The envelope provides slight initial resistance and the balloon yields like a tomato.

utilizationMethod: Grip the MacBook by its hinge edge as if it were a hammer handle. Use the laptop’s main body as the ‘hammerhead,’ orienting the heavier screen section forward to achieve a head-heavy bias. Wrap a 2 cm wide strip of tape around the hinge area to approximate the round handle diameter, and swing the assembly to feel the torque toward the screen end.

virtualObjectInfo.inertia: relatively heavy with the center of mass concentrated at one end
virtualObjectInfo.hapticFeedback: Grasp the round handle and immediately sense a substantial overall weight (head-heavy bias). The handle is smooth and cylindrical (≈2 cm diameter), filling your palm comfortably. When you lift or swing, you feel the center of mass strongly toward the hammerhead end, creating a torque in your wrist. The head itself is rigid and dense under impact, delivering a sharp impulse on contact. A small machinist’s hammer or tack hammer—with a solid metal head, round handle, and the same head-heavy balance—is the ideal physical proxy.

Orient the bulk of the headset forward so its heavier lenses and electronics act as the hammerhead. Swing it in a hammering motion to sense the forward-biased center of mass and feel the abrupt stop on impact with a soft surface.
